A 6-month-old infant is admitted with severe vomiting and requires placement of a gastric tube. The nurse sets up the feeding equipment as shown in the image. Which of the following tubes is correctly depicted in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Infant feeding tube Explanation: The tube depicted in the image is an infant feeding tube, which is smaller in diameter and more flexible compared to a standard nasogastric (NG) tube. Infant feeding tubes are specifically designed for use in newborns and young infants due to their smaller anatomy and inability to tolerate a larger NG tube. Nasogastric (NG) Tubes: (Option A) Inserted through the nose and passed into the stomach Larger in diameter (typically 14-18 French) Common markings: Measurement markings in centimeters to indicate the insertion depth 'STOMACH' printed on the tube to confirm correct placement Indications: Decompression of the stomach (e.g., in intestinal obstruction) Enteral feeding in adults and older children Medication administration Infant Feeding Tubes: (Option B) Smaller in diameter (typically 5-8 French)

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a choledochotomy for the removal of common bile duct stones. The surgeon decides to use the given tube during the procedure. Which of the following statements best describes its correct use and function in this scenario?

options.A: It is inserted to provide long-term biliary drainage and should be left in place for several months.
options.B: It acts as a stent and is retained for 4-6 weeks in the distal filling defect.
options.C: It is used to create a biliary-enteric anastomosis and is removed immediately after surgery.
options.D: It is placed to perform intraoperative cholangiography and is removed before closing the incision.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It acts as a stent and is retained for 4-6 weeks in the distal filling defect. After the longitudinal incision in choledochotomy, the T-tube is inserted to act as a stent. T-tube has a horizontal part which is placed in the CBD and vertical part which is allowed to come out, to drain bile. Amount of bile draining daily is measured. Before removal of the T-tube, patency of CBD should be confirmed. T-tube is retained for 4-6 weeks in a distal filling defect. questions.explanation: banding/sclerotherapy/gluing. Correct Answer: A. This instrument is commonly used when variceal bleeding does not stop after banding, sclerotherapy, or gluing. The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary balloon tamponade device used to control severe esophageal variceal bleeding when initial endoscopic treatments fail. It acts as a bridge to definitive therapy (like band ligation, sclerotherapy, or TIPS). questions.question: Which of the following statements about the following instrument in the image is incorrect?

options.A: The catheter is coated with silicone to minimize irritation during prolonged use.
options.B: For self-retaining purposes, the balloon is inflated with 20-30 ml of saline.
options.C: It can be used for administration of intravesical chemotherapy
options.D: 2-way foley’s catheter can be used for bladder irrigation following TURP

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2-way Foley’s catheter can be used for bladder irrigation following TURP catheter is used for draining clots in patients with haematuria and clot retention, following transurethral prostate or bladder surgery. Material LATEX - Less irritation & crust formation Silicone Coating- For Prolonged use (upto 3 months) (Option A) Types 2-way Foley catheter 3-way Foley catheter Channels 2-way Foley catheter: Main channel: For drainage of urine Small channel: For inflating balloon 3-way Foley catheter: Main channel: for drainage of urine Additional channel for irrigation Balloon Inflation 20-30 ml saline for self-retaining (Option B) 30-50 ml of saline for hemostatic compression effect Sizes (French scale) Pediatric patients : 4, 6, 8, 10 Adult patients: 12, 14, 16, 18 Size Calculation Outer diameter of catheter in mm = Fr/3 (Fr - French units) E.g, if the size of the catheter is 18 French, then diameter = 18/3 = 6mm Uses To relieve urinary retention To measure urine output For administration of intravesical chemotherapy (Option C) 3 ways catheter - for Irrigation after TURP May be used for supra-pubic cystostomy

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient is rushed to the emergency department with symptoms of acute limb ischemia. The vascular surgeon diagnoses an arterial embolism and decides to perform an embolectomy. Which of the following catheters is specifically designed and most appropriate for this procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Fogarty Catheter Explanation: Fogarty Embolectomy Catheter is used in embolectomy to treat arterial or venous thrombus/emboli in blood vessels. The correct procedure for using the catheter: Insertion through the clot Inflation beyond the embolus Withdrawal to remove the clot Swan-Ganz catheter (Option A) is used for hemodynamic monitoring using pulmonary artery catheterization, not for embolectomy. De-Pezzer Self-Retaining Catheter (Option C) & Malecot Catheter (Option D) are used for urinary drainage and related procedures, not for vascular embolectomy.

questions.question: Match the following: a. Foley’s catheter 1. b. Nelaton’s catheter 2. c. Malecot’s catheter 3. d. Red-rubber catheter 4.
All of the following are true statements regarding central venous catheters except-

options.A: The tip of the catheter is situated in the inferior vena cava
options.B: The most dangerous complication is pneumothorax
options.C: Inside OT, the Internal jugular vein is the preferred vein
options.D: In acutely injured, critically ill patients Femoral vein is the preferred vein

questions.explanation: central venous catheter is situated in the superior vena cava, not on the inferior vena cava. The central venous catheter is used for fluid, medication, and nutrition administration. The tip is located in the superior vena cava Order of preference: Subclavian vein > Internal jugular vein > Femoral vein (Option D) Inside OT: Internal jugular vein (Option C) Outside OT: Subclavian vein Complications: catheter-related sepsis, pneumothorax (Option B) Reference: Central Venous Catheter Insertion - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: All of the following about chemo-port is true, except

options.C: The catheter is placed beneath the skin
options.D: The veins used are the internal jugular and subclavian veins.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Retained for 5 years Explanation: Chemoport is an implantable venous access device which is placed beneath the skin. (Option C) It is retained for 1-2 years. The veins used are the internal jugular vein and the subclavian vein. (Option D) Used for chemotherapy administration. (Option B) In the chemo port, there are palpation pumps with which we can feel the presence of the septum. Complications- catheter embolization, port occlusion, vascular thrombosis. Reference: https://www.moffitt.org/treatments/chemotherapy/what-is-a-chemo-port/
